pages.text: There was a time when witches and warlocks could not freely practice their craft from their towers or huts in the middle of forests or swamps. The Inquisition spilled much blood, organizing regular hunts for all who were knowledgeable - from village healers to herbalists curing livestock diseases.
A caricature illustrating society's attitude towards sorcerers during those times - diminutive figures in comical hats.

pages.title: Witch Hunts
pages.text: Many historians argue that the reason enchantresses often left towns and villages, seeking refuge in dark forests and impenetrable swamps, was the fear of the pyre. Their magic adapted, they discovered new sources of power, thus giving birth to the modern art of witchcraft as we know it today. One can only ponder what is more - knowledge lost in the fire of the Inquisition or secrets discovered by mages who fled to the swamps.
Troops of soldiers and inquisitors combing the forests, armed with torches, in the fight against witchcraft, set fire to even centuries ago abandoned and half-drowned huts.
